sections: This report was written by Julia Rock.

Good things are happening! A new state is on the verge of implementing a $15 minimum wage, and McDonald’s workers are getting ready to strike to demand the fast food giant does the same. Meanwhile, progressives across the country are finding ways to ensure the wealthy pay a fair tax burden — and that could include the inheritors of Jeff Bezos’ Amazon fortune.

The rest of this You Love To See It, exclusive for paid subscribers, is listed below. Become a paid subscriber at the link below to access all of our exclusive content, our podcasts, our live events, and The Citizens’ Guide To Holding The Powerful Accountable.
Things That You Love To See:
McDonald's Workers Will Strike for $15 an Hour in 15 Cities

: “McDonald's cashiers and cooks in 15 U.S. cities will strike on May 19 — a day before the fast-food behemoth's annual shareholder meeting — to demand McDonald's pay all of its workers at least $15 an hour amid a national labor shortage in the fast food industry,”
Jeff Bezos' Heirs Might Have To Pay The Taxes He Is Avoiding

: If President Joe Biden’s tax plan becomes law as it is currently written, Jeff Bezos’ heirs would owe tens of billions of dollars in taxes on the money they inherit from him. That’s because Biden’s plan includes a repeal of the so-called step-up rule, which currently allows investors to pass on assets to their heirs without paying taxes on the capital gains from those assets.
Congress Looks To Judicial Overrides To Strengthen Consumer Protections

: Lawmakers are preparing to leverage the power of the judicial override to reverse a recent U.S. Supreme Court decision “that would limit the ability of the Federal Trade Commission to seek monetary relief for borrowers who have been defrauded by corporate lenders,”

reports. “With a simple tweak to the legislative text — which can pass on an individual basis or as part of an omnibus package — a so-called judicial override can address or eliminate whatever ambiguity the Supreme Court found within the law, thereby nullifying the court’s decision.”
68 Nobel Laureates Demand DOJ Review Prosecution of Steven Donziger

: “Dozens of Nobel Laureates are demanding the U.S. Department of Justice immediately intervene and block the controversial misdemeanor contempt prosecution of U.S. human rights attorney Steven Donziger by a private Chevron law firm appointed by a judge with investments in Chevron,” according to a press release by Donziger’s defense team.
